content: Title I of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section defining terms related to oversight of brokers and dealers. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 is amended to define terms related to audits and audit reports for issuers, brokers, and dealers. An audit is an examination of financial statements by an independent public accounting firm to express an opinion. An audit report is a document prepared after an audit for compliance with securities laws. The term 'professional standards' refers to accounting principles established by standard-setting bodies under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. The professional standards under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 include auditing standards, quality control policies, ethical standards, and independence standards determined by the Board or the Commission. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 establishes professional standards including auditing, quality control, ethics, and independence determined by the Board or Commission. The Act defines a broker as one required to file financial statements certified by a registered public accounting firm, and a dealer as one required to file financial statements. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 sets professional standards for auditing, quality control, ethics, and independence. It defines a broker as needing certified financial statements and a dealer as requiring financial statements. The Act also establishes the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and expands its scope to include brokers and dealers. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 amends sections related to registration with the Board, auditing, and independence standards for issuers, brokers, and dealers. It expands the scope of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board to include brokers and dealers. In amendments to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, sections related to auditing and inspections of registered public accounting firms are revised to include brokers and dealers. Investigations and disciplinary proceedings are also updated to encompass brokers and dealers. Amendments to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 include adding brokers and dealers to sections related to auditing and inspections of registered public accounting firms. Investigations and disciplinary proceedings are also expanded to cover brokers and dealers. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 amendments include adding brokers and dealers to auditing and inspections of accounting firms. Allocation of Accounting Support Fees among brokers and dealers is specified in subsection (h). The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 amendments include adding brokers and dealers to auditing and inspections of accounting firms. Allocation of Accounting Support Fees among brokers and dealers is specified in subsection (h). Brokers and dealers' allocation of fees is based on net capital compared to total net capital of all brokers and dealers, in accordance with Board rules. Every broker or dealer is obligated to pay their share of the annual accounting support fee. Investigations can be referred to a self-regulatory organization under certain circumstances. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 includes amendments related to auditing and inspections of accounting firms, now extending to brokers and dealers. The allocation of accounting support fees among brokers and dealers is specified in subsection (h), based on net capital compared to the total net capital of all brokers and dealers. Investigations can be referred to a self-regulatory organization under certain circumstances, specifically concerning audit reports for brokers or dealers under their jurisdiction. The amendments made by this Act will be effective 180 days after enactment.
